intro: Pinus arizonica subsp. stormiae, commonly known as the Arizona white pine, is a subspecies native to the southwestern United States and northwestern Mexico. It is a coniferous evergreen tree characterized by its slender, cylindrical trunk and needle-like leaves arranged in bundles of five. The tree produces cones that are typically 5–8 centimeters long, containing oval-shaped seeds. Its bark is thin and smooth when young, becoming fissured with age. This subspecies is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, thriving in well-drained soils and full sun.
